questions.text: A 28-year-old man returns from a beach vacation in Goa. He presents with an intensely itchy, serpiginous, raised lesion on his foot as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A 32-year-old sewage worker presents with acute onset of fever, myalgia, conjunctival suffusion, and mild jaundice. He has recently worked barefoot during heavy rainfall. Blood cultures are sterile. Which of the following is considered the gold standard test for confirming the diagnosis of this disease?

A 25-year-old male undergoes a kidney transplant due to chronic renal failure. His monozygotic twin volunteers to donate one of his kidneys. Post-transplant, the patient does not require long-term immunosuppressive therapy and shows no signs of rejection. Which type of graft has been performed in this patient?
What are the clinical features caused by the organism shown in the image.

choices.text: Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) of Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with high fever, diffuse rash, hypotension, and multiorgan involvement following a recent skin infection. Laboratory tests reveal elevated cytokine levels. Which of the following bacterial toxins is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) of Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A patient during a routine ANC checkup underwent a TORCH profile where she came positive for anti- IgM Rubella antibodies. She decided to continue the pregnancy. Six months later the child was born with symptoms suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. All can be seen in the child except:

A 60-year-old man with COPD develops pneumonia after staying in a hotel with central air conditioning. His sputum gram stain is inconclusive. A special medium containing glutamate, cysteine and charcoal is used for diagnosis. Which of the following organisms is best cultured using this medium?
Identify the antibody by its structure.

A 40-year-old man who regularly eats raw freshwater fish presents with fatigue and glossitis. Labs reveal macrocytic anemia with low serum vitamin B12 levels. Which of the following parasites is the most likely cause?

choices.text: The organism has an efflux pump that removes beta-lactams
The organism has an altered penicillin-binding protein
The organism lacks a cell wall

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with low-grade fever, persistent dry cough, and malaise for the past 10 days. Chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates. The physician suspects atypical pneumonia. Which of the following best explains why beta-lactams are ineffective in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The organism lacks a cell wall

questions.text: A 23-year-old male who recently returned from a backpacking trip across rural Africa presents with hematuria and dysuria. On urine microscopy showed this image. All of the following features helps differentiate this organism from trematodes except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Man as the definitive host

questions.text: A 26-year-old man visited a rabies clinic for administration of anti-rabies immunoglobulin after getting bitten by a dog. What kind of immunity is this?

A 32-year-old woman on broad-spectrum antibiotics develops thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge with itching and soreness. Vaginal pH is normal (≤4.5). KOH prep of the discharge will show what morphology?

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory investigations would most accurately confirm the diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Antigen detection in the stool sample

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is true, but the Reason is false
Assertion is false, but the Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Antigenic drift results in a gradual, sequential change in the antigenic structure of the influenza virus.

 

Reason (R): The new antigens formed by antigenic drift are completely unrelated to the previous viral antigens.

 

Choose the correct option:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Assertion is true, but the Reason is false

choices.text: It is more resistant than mecA-positive MRSA
It encodes PBP-2c, a variant of PBP-2a
It is only found in community-acquired MRSA strains
It is resistant to vancomycin as well

questions.text: A researcher isolates a highly resistant Staphylococcus aureus strain from a hospital-acquired infection and finds that it carries mecC instead of mecA. Which of the following statements best describes the clinical significance of mecC-positive MRSA?
questions.solution: Ans. B) It encodes PBP-2c, a variant of PBP-2a

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory is testing the effectiveness of a sterilization method that involves DNA damage without raising temperature. The efficacy of this method is assessed using a standard biological indicator organism. Which of the following is the most appropriate test organism?

A 35-year-old man who recently returned from a conflict zone presents with fever and generalized rash. On examination, he is febrile and found to have body lice in his clothing. The rash is widespread but notably spares the palms and soles. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?

A 47-year-old man working in an abattoir presents with a painless pustule on his forearm that evolved into a black-centered ulcer with surrounding edema. He recently handled raw animal hides. A smear is taken from the ulcer and sent for laboratory evaluation to identify the causative organism. Which of the following stains is most appropriate to detect the likely pathogen responsible for this lesion?

choices.text: Transmitted via mosquito bite; infective form is promastigote
Transmitted via ingestion of cysts; infective form is trophozoite
Transmitted by fecal contamination from Reduvid bug; infective form is metacyclic trypomastigote
Transmitted by tick bite; infective form is sporozoite

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from a rural village in South America presents with fever, swelling around the eye (Romaña sign), and malaise. He recalls waking up with an insect bite on his face. Examination and blood smear suggest infection with a protozoan parasite. Which of the following statements best describes the transmission and infective form of the organism responsible?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Transmitted by fecal contamination from Reduvid bug; infective form is metacyclic trypomastigote

choices.text: To determine the virus strain or serotype
To qualitatively assess cytopathic effect of virus
To confirm the presence of the virus in a clinical sample
To quantify the number of infectious viral particles

questions.text: In a virology research lab, a scientist is working on measuring the infectivity of a newly isolated virus. A plaque assay is performed using a monolayer of host cells. Each clear zone that appears corresponds to viral lysis of host cells. What is the primary purpose of performing this plaque assay?
questions.solution: Ans. D) To quantify the number of infectious viral particles

questions.text: A 22-year-old traveller returns from East Africa and is evaluated for fever, chills, and malaise. Blood smear reveals ring-stage parasites inside red blood cells. Further testing is ordered to confirm the species. The patient is found to be negative for Duffy blood group antigen. This genetic trait provides resistance against which of the following Plasmodium species?

A 6-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of perianal itching, especially at night, and irritability. Her mother reports that the child has been scratching her bottom frequently. A tape test is performed, revealing these eggs. Identify the worm causing this disease.

A 30-year-old male presents with pruritic, scaly lesions on his groin and inner thighs. He reports that the rash has been persistent and worsens during warm, humid weather. A fungal culture revealed this image. What is the most likely organism causing this disease?

A 30-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with a persistent dry cough, fever, and progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. A chest X-ray shows bilateral ground-glass opacities. Gomori methenamine silver stain of sputum showed this image. Identify the organism.

A 28-year-old male marathon runner consumes a high-carbohydrate meal after completing a long race. In response to the postprandial rise in blood glucose, insulin levels increases. Within liver cells, glucose is rapidly phosphorylated to form glucose-6-phosphate (G6P). G6P then follows several anabolic and energy-storage pathways characteristic of the fed state. Which of the following are possible physiological fates of glucose-6-phosphate in this postprandial (fed) state?

 

  1. Conversion to pyruvate and entry into the TCA cycle for ATP production
  2. Storage as glycogen
  3. Entry into the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) to generate NADPH and ribose
  4. Conversion to acetyl-CoA for fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis
  5. Conversion to glucose and release into the bloodstream

A 22-year-old man presents with darkening of urine upon standing and complaints of joint stiffness. His family history reveals a pattern of similar symptoms in his father. On further metabolic screening, increased homogentisic acid is detected in the urine. Given the suspicion of an inborn error of metabolism, the physician recalls a classical group of disorders described by Garrod. Which of the following combinations correctly represents Garrod's tetrad of inborn errors of metabolism?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Alkaptonuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, Albinism

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is evaluated for behavioral issues and physical abnormalities. On examination, he is noted to have brittle, coarse hair, malar rash, long and thin limbs, pectus excavatum, scoliosis, muscle hypotonia, and ectopia lentis (dislocated lens). His developmental history includes mild intellectual disability. Laboratory workup is ordered to identify a possible inborn error of metabolism. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to be elevated in this patient?

choices.text: NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased
Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle
Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased
The major fuel used by the brain is glucose

questions.text: A 25-year-old healthy individual is assessed during a routine wellness checkup shortly after consuming a carbohydrate-rich meal. The physician wants to evaluate the body’s typical metabolic adaptations in the well-fed (postprandial) state. Which of the following statements correctly describes a metabolic feature of this well-fed state?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The major fuel used by the brain is glucose

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with intermittent abdominal pain, tingling sensations in her hands and feet, and occasional muscle weakness. Her parents report that she has a habit of chewing wall paint from their recently renovated home. Physical exam shows pallor and mild cognitive slowing. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia with basophilic stippling. Which of the following enzymes are most likely inhibited in her condition?

 

  1. ALA synthase
  2. ALA dehydratase
  3. PBG synthase (also known as ALA dehydratase)
  4. Ferrochelatase
This unique absorption pattern is shown by which analyte?

A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with prolonged fasting hypoglycemia. The physician explains that the liver compensates by producing glucose through gluconeogenesis. For the conversion of 2 molecules of pyruvate to 1 molecule of glucose, the energy requirements are:

A preterm neonate is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) with signs of respiratory distress, including nasal flaring, chest retractions, and cyanosis. The mother had a complicated pregnancy resulting in preterm labor at 30 weeks of gestation. The attending neonatologist suspects Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (NRDS) due to immature lung development. From a biochemical perspective, a deficiency of which phospholipid is most likely contributing to the infant's condition?

choices.text: Glycogen storage disease due to hexosaminidase A deficiency
Lysosomal storage disease due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency
Lysosomal storage disease due to sphingomyelinase deficiency
Glycogen storage disease due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with developmental delay, hepatosplenomegaly, and progressive neurodegeneration. On examination, the child is hypotonic, has a protuberant abdomen, and shows signs of motor regression. An ophthalmologic exam reveals a cherry-red spot on the macula. Based on clinical suspicion, enzyme assay is ordered. Which of the following accurately describes the metabolic defect and classifies the disease in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lysosomal storage disease due to sphingomyelinase deficiency

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is participating in a clinical study investigating the metabolic effects of fasting. After an 18-hour fast, researchers collect tissue samples and analyze glucose transporter expression in various tissues. They observe that glucose uptake remains constant in some tissues, while in others, it is significantly reduced. The reduction is attributed to decreased insulin signaling, which affects certain insulin-dependent glucose transporters. In which of the following tissues is glucose uptake most likely to be decreased due to reduced transporter activity during prolonged fasting?

A 45-year-old patient with gout is being treated with allopurinol, which inhibits xanthine oxidase in the purine degradation pathway. To better understand purine metabolism, which of the following correctly identifies the nitrogen donors for the N-7 and N-9 positions during de novo purine ring synthesis?
Thiamine level is best monitored by:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Thiamine level in blood

choices.text: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited from both parents.
Mitochondrial DNA has a lower mutation rate than nuclear DNA.
Mitochondrial DNA encodes more than 25% of the proteins involved in oxidative phosphorylation.
Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a genetics clinic for counseling after her mother was recently diagnosed with a mitochondrial disorder. The physician explains the inheritance pattern and some molecular features of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). Which of the following statements correctly reflects a characteristic of mitochondrial DNA?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with signs of sepsis following orthopedic surgery. Blood cultures reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters. To differentiate between methicillin-sensitive and methicillin-resistant strains and to identify the specific Staphylococcus species involved, the microbiology lab employs Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis on the bacterial DNA. Which of the following sequences is most likely to be the target site for the restriction enzyme used in this analysis?
The sequence of the template DNA strand is 5'-GATATC-3'. What will be the sequence of RNA produced?

choices.text: Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.
Inhibits the binding of apo B to the LDL receptor, thus blocking uptake of the lipoprotein and raising blood cholesterol levels.
Increases the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine.
Increases the synthesis and secretion of VLDL in the liver, leading to increased LDL formation in the blood.

questions.text: Compounds which inhibit the action of the recently discovered protein, proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9), have been identified as a potential antiatherogenic drugs because PCSK9:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.

questions.text: Patient with high TG esterified with LCFA presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis?

choices.text: It enhances the urea cycle enzyme activity
It increases ammonia excretion via the kidneys
It promotes nitrogen excretion by forming alternative products
It supplies missing urea cycle intermediates

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with lethargy, vomiting, and confusion. His past medical history reveals a diagnosis of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, a type of urea cycle disorder. Laboratory results show hyperammonemia. He is started on intravenous fluids and given sodium phenylbutyrate as part of management. What is the primary mechanism by which phenylbutyrate helps in this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) It promotes nitrogen excretion by forming alternative products

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
An enzyme catalyzes a reaction where the substrate concentration is 1000 times than Km. If the substrate concentration is doubled, what will happen to the reaction velocity?
questions.solution: Ans. C) It will stay the same

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5' capping?

During clinical rounds, a 55-year-old woman undergoes routine blood work at 8:00 AM. However, due to laboratory delays, the blood sample is processed only at 11:00 AM. Her blood glucose level is reported as 48 mg/dL, which is significantly lower than expected, while other parameters are within normal limits. The attending physician suspects a pre-analytical error. Which enzyme is primarily inhibited by fluoride to prevent a false decrease in glucose concentration in vitro?

choices.text: Increased anaerobic metabolism due to hypoxia
Increased aerobic glycolysis with lactate production

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, fatigue, and a persistent cough. A chest CT reveals a mass in the right upper lobe of the lung. A biopsy confirms non-small cell lung carcinoma. A PET scan is ordered, which reveals increased uptake of 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the tumor. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon in tumour cell?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased aerobic glycolysis with lactate production

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete follows a high-fat, low-carbohydrate ketogenic diet. During prolonged exercise, his muscles rely on β-oxidation of fatty acids for ATP production. Stearic acid (C18:0), a saturated long-chain fatty acid, undergoes complete β-oxidation in the mitochondria. What is the net ATP yield from the complete oxidation of one molecule of stearic acid?
